Course Summary

Drydocks World Dubai, Jebel Ali Port and Mubarak Marine, together with AqualisBraemar, have organised a Ship Familiarisation Course targeted at the local and international shipping industry and intended to familiarize professionals in the industry with ships, ship repair, casualties and have a more hands on view of the industry and its fundamental assets, ships.  This course is/was primarily intended for younger claims handlers, brokers, lawyers etc., all of whom may deal with casualties and surveys in their daily work, but who have generally had no seagoing experience or even been on board one of the vessels or units which they deal with.

The course involves two days within Dubai drydocks, which opened with presentations from the yard senior management and AqualisBraemar personnel from our Marine, Energy and Offshore divisions. Thereafter, the delegates were taken on a tour of the entire yard, including a walk through the bottom of the largest (500 m long) drydock, the floating dock and the flooding dock, plus all of the yard workshops. The delegates had an opportunity to board and tour a jack up rig, a VLCC and a large bulk carrier during their tour. On the third day the delegates were given a guided tour of Terminal 3 at Jebel Ali port container terminal and were able to visit the container terminal control room and the Harbour Master’s control room.  The course concluded with an afternoon visit to the yard of Mubarak marine at Dubai Maritime City, where the delegates listened to a presentation of large casualties in the area where Mubarak had been involved. The delegates also toured the 400 tonne capacity sheer legs crane, “Al Amlak”. 

When we ran this course for the first time in early 2016, we had 15 delegates covering law firms, salvors, underwriters, brokers, port authorities and ship financiers. The 2017 course had 20 attendees, whilst there were only 12 at the most recent course, reflecting tight controls on costs from the London Market, which did not send any delegates this year (10 in 2017).

The next course is intended to be run in the Autumn/Winter of 2021.
